video.title: College Algebra - Full Course
video.description:
Learn Algebra in this full college course. These concepts are often used in programming.

This course was created by Dr. Linda Green, a lecturer at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Check out her YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCkyLJh6hQS1TlhUZxOMjTFw 

⭐️ Lecture Notes ⭐️
🔗 Algebra Notes: http://lindagreen.web.unc.edu/files/2020/08/classNotes_m110_2018F.pdf

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Exponent Rules
⌨️ (0:10:14) Simplifying using Exponent Rules
⌨️ (0:21:18) Simplifying Radicals
⌨️ (0:31:46) Factoring
⌨️ (0:45:08) Factoring - Additional Examples
⌨️ (0:55:37) Rational Expressions
⌨️ (1:05:00) Solving Quadratic Equations
⌨️ (1:15:22) Rational Equations
⌨️ (1:25:31) Solving Radical Equations
⌨️ (1:37:01) Absolute Value Equations
⌨️ (1:42:23) Interval Notation
⌨️ (1:49:35) Absolute Value Inequalities
⌨️ (1:56:55) Compound Linear Inequalities
⌨️ (2:05:59) Polynomial and Rational Inequalities
⌨️ (2:16:20) Distance Formula
⌨️ (2:20:59) Midpoint Formula
⌨️ (2:23:30) Circles: Graphs and Equations
⌨️ (2:33:06) Lines: Graphs and Equations
⌨️ (2:41:35) Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
⌨️ (2:49:05) Functions
⌨️ (3:00:53) Toolkit Functions
⌨️ (3:08:00) Transformations of Functions
⌨️ (3:20:29) Introduction to Quadratic Functions
⌨️ (3:23:54) Graphing Quadratic Functions
⌨️ (3:33:02) Standard Form and Vertex Form for Quadratic Functions
⌨️ (3:37:18) Justification of the Vertex Formula
⌨️ (3:41:11) Polynomials
⌨️ (3:49:06) Exponential Functions
⌨️ (3:56:53) Exponential Function Applications
⌨️ (4:08:38) Exponential Functions Interpretations
⌨️ (4:18:17) Compound Interest
⌨️ (4:29:33) Logarithms: Introduction
⌨️ (4:38:15) Log Functions and Their Graphs
⌨️ (4:48:59) Combining Logs and Exponents
⌨️ (4:53:38) Log Rules
⌨️ (5:02:10) Solving Exponential Equations Using Logs
⌨️ (5:10:20) Solving Log Equations
⌨️ (5:19:27) Doubling Time and Half Life
⌨️ (5:35:34) Systems of Linear Equations
⌨️ (5:47:36) Distance, Rate, and Time Problems
⌨️ (5:53:20) Mixture Problems
⌨️ (5:59:48) Rational Functions and Graphs
⌨️ (6:13:13) Combining Functions
⌨️ (6:17:10) Composition of Functions
⌨️ (6:29:32) Inverse Functions

--

topLevelComment.author: Alex antoni
topLevelComment.text:
Hello everyone, I have a question for anyone whose kind to reply. Why can’t we cancel out (x-1) top and bottom at min 1:04:07?

Thank you in advance, and thank you proffesor for this content!

replies.author: Alex antoni
replies.text: @T.I.N.D thank you ever so much!

replies.author: T.I.N.D
replies.text:
Great question
We can’t simplify because when either the denominator (bottom) or the numerator (top) have addition AND/OR subtraction we can’t reduce, but if they had ONLY division or multiplication in BOTH then we can reduce.

For example 
(1x+2)(3x+9)
———————
(1x+2)(4x+1)
Is reducible to 
(3x+9)
———-
(4x+1)
Because these are strictly undergoing multiplication 
(3x+2)- 1
—————
(3x+2)
Is not reducible because of subtraction.

EDIT: I answered this on mobile im sorry if it looks weird on computer

topLevelComment.author: makki
topLevelComment.text:
quick and short correction at 6:06:03

plugging in x=2 to get the y-coordinate of the hole means getting 3(2+2) / (2+5), not (2+7), making the y-coordinate 12/7 instead of 4/3. If you plot the equation at an online graphing calculator, (2,12/7) is the correct coordinate for the hole.

topLevelComment.text: at 1:55:41 , how can a number range from -inf to +inf if it is >= -3, shouldn't it start from (-3,+inf)?? pls explain this....

replies.author: makki
replies.text:
she means that any x-value from -inf to +inf satisfies the inequality for anything under an absolute value must be greater than or equal to zero (meaning it's always either zero or a positive number). 

plug in any x value (as long as it's a real number) to | 4x +5 | and you'd always either get a positive or zero value, making it _always_ greater than -3

topLevelComment.author: On the wave
topLevelComment.text:
I am studying in Russia and we solve the first equation 37:20 much easier:
x^2-6x+8=0
According to the theorem, the inverse of Vieta's theorem, we get:
x1 + x2 = 6 (we write the opposite sign of the number at the second x)
x1 * x2 = 8 (we leave the sign of the last number)
and now we select the numbers, i.e. so that it turns out that two x's in total and in their product gave 6 and 8. We get that X1 = 2 ; X2 = 4
If you don't believe me, then I will substitute these numbers into these 2 equations :
x1 + x2 = 2+4=6
x1 * x2 = 2*4=8

use it for your health))

topLevelComment.author: Sloppy Puppy
topLevelComment.text: I see the modularity of the solution for 1:25:49 , however I think its much simpler to just say that sqrt(x) = t & x = sqrt(x^2) then replace the sqrt(x) with t in original equation, use the quadratic formula and then replace the answers you get for t1/2 with sqrt(x) in which case you get sqrt(x) = 3 /^2 which is x = 9, while solution of sqrt(x) = -4 is impossible in the domain of real numbers, leaving you with final answer as x = 9.

replies.author: SEVENHEART
replies.text:
If you said that you had tried both way, but you couldn't get the second one to work. Alright, there must be the mistake in you factoring

I'll explain. First I want to tell you that either way is fine.

From 5x^2  -14x  +18, write them in 2 ways.
1. 5x^2  -4x  -10x  +8
2. 5x^2  -10x  -4x +8

factor the 1. you get 
x(5x  -4)  -2(5x  -4)
    (x  -2)(5x  -4)  result of 1.

factor the 2. you get 
5x(x  -2)  -4(x  -2)  
   (5x  -4)(x  -2)  result of 2.

IT"S THE SAME!


See that the 2nd way thus works as well.

Edit : The mistake

replies.author: rpruneau68
replies.text:
As someone who has taken advanced math courses and struggled many times during this process I can offer the following:
I was told we really don't comprehend the math concepts that we are exposed to until we reach the next level and have to utilize those concepts in order to manipulate the information to fit a form we understand how to solve.  

We learn algebra so we can have those required tools in order to solve higher levels of math problems, such as trigonometry, calculus, differential calculus.  Just like we learned how to add. subtract, multiply, divide, manipulate fractions, solve for Lower Common Divisible or identify prime numbers in preparation for Algebra concepts.

We forget or never had a good understanding of the lower level math concepts and have difficulty learning new material since we are struggling with getting over the hurdle of relearning material we may have struggled with in the past.

Thankfully, there are plenty of resources out there to help reinforce those concepts that we were lacking and take the "math speak" and change it to "English" or our own native tongue.
Sometimes we have to take a step back in order to advance which we will do so with a better foundation and the time spent refreshing previously learned concepts will not be wasted. 

I witnessed Nursing students and others who had non-technical majors not capable of grasping basic concepts in chemistry, electrical or other courses that required a small amount of algebraic manipulation in order to solve basic equations or better visualize concepts.  They were so focused on the stigmatism that math sucks and they couldn't do it that they did poorly and in reality it was just a matter of moving some items to the other side of the equation to balance them out.

Don't get too hung-up on this math stuff, just realize it builds on itself and if you are struggling with a concept, chances are its because you may need a refresher is some concepts you may be fuzzy.  Also, since there is a bunch of resource material and your instructor may not have the best teaching skills that suite your style of learning, use the internet to supplement those teachings.

I find Khanacademy .org has one of the most comprehensive and free learning platforms when it comes to math and other technical subjects.  This video too is a great resource so I am sure you may find others on this platform as well.  In addition, helping others learn while we are studying also increases our understanding of topics since we are required to explain thos concepts in better detail.

Keep going it gets better...

you're supposed to use soft brackets () in case of  negative infinity and positive infinity
you use hard brackets [ ] when there's a closed circle on number line or the notation has >= , <=

[ ] ------> used for closed circle, and >= <=

topLevelComment.author: Mr. Rich B.O.B 👑
topLevelComment.text:
4:50 — I have never liked this rule.  It makes no sense, cannot be tested, and just seems like a way to try and one-up someone at some point in history.  Like a teacher lost this bet while drunk and taught it to their students and it won-out.  It is the same thing as arguing over quotation marks.  English has no rules for how to use quotation marks.  It is free-reign.  It stands out in my mind that anything to the 0 power must be itself, as there is nothing to workout.

     2² is 4, but it is also 2*2.  The same 2³² is 4,294,967,296, but it is also 2*2*2...2*2*2.  Therefore when trying to expand 2⁰, you get... 1! no.  You get 2.  Ergo:

     2⁰ = 2
     4⁰ = 4
     3⁰ = 3
     87⁰ = 87
     0⁰ = 0

     If you are trying to do math with nothing, you have nothing to work with.

     This testibly proves true with anything divided by 0:

     1/0 = 1
     2/0 = 2
     69,420/0 = a stupid meme that needs to die, and so forth.

     I am reminded of the adage: _two halves do not make a whole—disagree? cut a baby in half and stick them back together, you do not have a whole baby, it's dead._

     And then you have the BS about negative Exponents.

replies.author: Nayaka
replies.text:
@roses are rosie  @roses are rosie  yep, she got 40 and 120 by adding 30r to both sides and subtracting 60 from both sides. The logic behind this is like a balance. 

Suppose the balance was already balanced (equal), if you either add or subract equal amounts of weight to both sides of the balance, it will stay balanced. Multiplying or dividing both sides also works with the same logic.

Here's a mathematical example:
You have 5=5, which is a true statement.
If you add 3 only to the right side, then it will be 5=8 which isn't true. But, if you add 3 to both sides you will get 8=8, which is true. That's an illustration on why we add, subtract, multiply, divide, etc both sides of the equation.

And lastly, why do we subtract in that part? Because by doing so, we can isolate the unknown variable (in this case, the unknown variable is r). By isolating, what I meant was to place it in a different side from the other terms, be it in the left side or the left side.

Why do we need to isolate the unknown variable? Because by doing so, we can find what the unknown variable is equal to. In this case, by isolating the variable she got 40r=120. 

From this we can easily find what r is equal to by dividing both sides by 40. Why 40? Because dividing 40r with 40 gives you r, and that's what we're searching for.

replies.author: Nayaka
replies.text:
When you use the square root sign √ you only get the positive root. If you want to get both positive and negative roots then you need to set it equal with a variable. 

For example, x²=25 can be simplified as x=±5.

In addition, if you want to find only the negative root then you add the negative sign in front of the square root sign. For example, -√25 is -5.

I hope this helps.

replies.author: Isaac Evans
replies.text: @billy bob joe omg thank u so much. At first I didn’t understand how (for the first example) 1/3 was equal to the cube root, but after u explained I got it. Then I used a calculator to double check and it worked. Thanks so much.

replies.author: billy bob joe
replies.text:
At 6:17,  for the first Ex: 64 1/3 = 3 √64= 4 this makes sense because 4 times 4 is 16 and 16 times 4 is 64. 
To break it down, the 3 on the outside of the root symbol comes from the fraction (which shows how many times you will need to multiply by) which is why the answer is 4.
Another example is 9 1/2 =  2√9=3   3 times 3 is 9, that's how the answer is 3, because 3 times 3 TWO  times (from the fraction) =9.
If it's the last example that is difficult, (5 1/3)³ =5 1/3⋅³=5¹=5, this makes sense because the power rule (raise a power to a power by multiplying the exponent) shows us we can multiply the 1/3 times ³. 1/3 times ³ is 1, 5¹ just equals 5.
I hope this helped, if not please tell me and I will try to explain it in a different way. We all learn differently.

replies.author: billy bob joe
replies.text: The answer is  (-∞,-3/4). If you look at the number line, the answer was supposed to show the numbers that they have together (green). It includes lower that -3/4 (not including -3/4) because that is the answer that both the colors were in (pink and blue). This does not include 18 because it does not align with the pink (-4+2>5). I hope this helps, if not, please tell me and I will try to explain it a different way.

replies.author: Nayaka
replies.text:
Actually √25 is just 5. Whenever you use the √ sign, you will only get the positive solution. It's different from this one:

x^2 = 25
x = ±√25
x = ±5

topLevelComment.author: Abdelkareem Elssokkary
topLevelComment.text:
1:29:20
Square root of 16 may be + or - 4
If (-4) the equation will be solved correctly.

replies.author: Nayaka
replies.text:
Whenever you use the √ sign, you only get the positive root. If you want to get both positive and negative solution then you need to set it equal to a variable, like x². For example:
16=x²
x=±4
In this case, yes, you get both positive and negative roots. Just in case you wanna get only the negative root, put the negative sign in front of the square root sign. Like -√16=-4

I am trying to study this thing in 1 day! We all have played 8 hours straight before.  I think I should do the same and put some dedication into my future college classes. I will update this message accordingly. 

2:02:00 Confused me when she put the reciprocal of -2/3 and typed  -3/2. I think that was a typo and I continue doing the equation with -2/3 while also changing the direction of the inequality symbol, which in fact ended up being the same answer. Am I right? or is there an explanation on why she type in -3/2?... By the way, you are a great instructor! Thank you so much for this video.

My first stop is at 3:20:36 to give my brain some sleep and rest. I will come back in 6-8 hours. This took me a total of 11 hours of my day. To follow along with notes and exercises takes longer than expected.

I finished the whole video, this is amazing. I was actually waiting to see some matrix on it but I was surprised at the end. Thank you for this video!

topLevelComment.author: G D
topLevelComment.text: @ 1:49 the product rule, Shouldn't it be 4 to the 7th in the exampler?

replies.author: Shu
replies.text: @G D well, when you add the exponents, you technically are multiplying the bases. See, (2*2*2) * (2*2*2*2) is basically just 2*2*2*2*2*2*2 which is 2 to the 7th power.

replies.author: G D
replies.text: @Shu so the bases are not multiplied? Just the exponents?

replies.author: Shu
replies.text: no, it shouldn't be 4 to the 7th power because that would make 16,384. It wouldn't make sense because 2 to the 3rd power is 8 and 2 to the 4th power is 16. 8 times 16 is 128. 2 to the 7th is also equivalent to 128. Therefore, 2 to the 7th is correct.

topLevelComment.text:
5:20 She forgot to begin with:
5^7 over 5^7.
And because of the quotient rule, you must subtract the top n with the bottom n to get to 0 or one.

Which is why she wrote 5^7 * 5^-7.

It confused me a lot as to why she wrote -7 as the second n. If it confused you too, this is why.

topLevelComment.author: gridcaster
topLevelComment.text:
I love education and teaching and learning...I still can't get my mind around how we turn this exact information into a commodity that can be sold to people for THOUSANDS of dollars when the exact same information is available for free.  Arguably, the free version is even better than a poorly run classroom by FAR.

It breaks my heart when I know students paying and sitting in a classroom turn to free sources of information to pass their courses.  The education system is antiquated and propped up by a guild-like structure based more on payment and attendance than actual learning.

How many thousands of dollars are wasted on purchasing a piece of paper saying you are a "graduate".  I'm not an enemy of formal classroom education, but its pretty clear that the face to face traditional format has not (in most places) kept up to pace with the change in information technology over the last twenty years --- or even the last five years.  Educational institutions ought to be forced to change or die...and yet, they somehow have managed to stay in business while profiting without changing much or anything at all.  It can't go on like this forever.

replies.author: Chandrani Chaki
replies.text: https://youtu.be/S8-97elM3ho😊

replies.author: Feeling special
replies.text:
We actually can find equations of a line by not only 2 points, but also with the slope of a line that is parallel or perpendicular to the asked line & one point. Since: 1) parallel lines have the same slopes and 2) perpendicular lines have opposite and reciprocal slopes, if we find the slope of the parall/perpen line by their given equation, we can determine our asked slopes and find the y-intersect by putting the values of the point into the equation. 
So we can find a slope either with 2 given points or with the slope of parallel/perpendicular slope
but we always need 1 point to find the y-intersect

replies.author: Feeling special
replies.text: The general equation of a line is: y=ax+b, where a-slope(gradient) & b-y-intersect (the point where y-axis intersects with a line). By finding a slope and y-intersects you can write the equation. You need 2 points of a line to find a slope (y2-y1/x2-x1) and 1 point to find a gradient (put the value of x and y of the point to the equation that we get, so you can find an only undefined number, which is b). Finally putting a and b into the equation you get a full equaiton of a line

replies.author: Feeling special
replies.text:
[I still don't understand why we need equation of a circle, but ]
The equation of circles is come from distance formula, cause we need to find the distance (a.k.a radius) of the point on the circumference. If we have the centre, we use (x-k(x of centre))^2 + (y-n(y of centre))^2=r^2 . If our centre is 0,0 the formula will be: x^2+y^2=r^2. If centre (0,k), formula: x^2+(y-k)^2=r^2. If centre (n,0), formula: (x-n)^2+y^2=r^2. 
If you see formulas like these in the problem, it means that the graph of the equation will be a circle.

replies.author: Feeling special
replies.text: we use midpoint formula to find (guess what?) the midpoint of a line, knowing the endpoints of the line. Since the midpoint is MIDpoint, its x and y is the MID of the endpoints, you just need to seperately add x-s and y-s and divide by 2.

replies.author: Rosemary Lyndall Wemm
replies.text: The good news is that educationally disadvantaged U.S. students can now catch up to their international counterparts with this excellent short course.  In the U.S. the same material usually takes years to get through.  Students in other countries are used to covering a lot more material in a much shorter time.  That's why we are not generally permitted to work at some job while studying at this level.

replies.author: Rosemary Lyndall Wemm
replies.text:
@Atlow In Australia, and in other countries, this is required if you apply for entry to tertiary studies or professional accreditation and you fail to satisfy the basic pre-requisite studies that are taught in Australian Senior High School.  
Before we left Australia for the USA, our last accountant, a New Zealander, was required to study for and pass an Australian Senior High School (Years 11 and 12) mathemetics subject in spite of the fact that he had graduated from New Zealand's Year 13 (Australian Year 12 equivalent) and had been working as an accredited accountant in New Zealand.  He was required to complete the Secondary School pre-requisite because he had not passed any equivalent course/program/class in New Zealand.  
This may seem strange to you because the US educational system teaches what other nations teach in the last couple of years of Secondary Education in their College Bachelor degree.  In Australia, the minimal entry requirement for entry to Year 1 of a Professional Bachelor Degrees in Medicine, Dentistry, Vetinary Science, and so on, is a high pass in FOUR (preferaby FIVE) American Level Advanced examinations in specific sciences and humanities OR acompleted, or near completed American Level Bachelor degree which contains the equivalent content of those specified subjects.  
Other non-US countries have similar academic levels for the average 15 and 16 year old. 
Entry to the first year of the long (6 year double Bachelor degree in Medicine and Surgery) requires a minimum of a US level Bachelor degree with a pre-med component.  Students with high passes in an Australian Year 12 tertiary orientated curriculum (equivalent to at least 5 American Advanced Placment examinations) are accepted into the short (5 year double Bachelor degree in Medicine and Surgery) in Ireland. 
You may have been gas-lighted into believing that the US has the highest educational standards / levels in the world, but this is very far from reality.

replies.author: Atlow
replies.text: @Rosemary Lyndall Wemm So what, you send grown ass men who've been out of school for 12 years back to high school? You can't possibly think that's actually a 'good idea' can you?

replies.author: Rosemary Lyndall Wemm
replies.text: @Atlow In Australia Algebra is taught in Years 7-10 and Calculus in Years 11 -12.  A pass in Algebra is a pre-requisite for entering Senior Secondary School (Years 11-12).  A pass in Calculus is a pre-requisite for entry to the first year of the standard Australian Pass (3 year) or Honors (4 year) Bachelor degree in most of the sciences.  You must return to Secondary School if you need to study Algebra and Senior Secondary School if you need to study Calculus.  The standard U.S. Bachelor level is much lower than the standard Australian / New Zealand / U.K. model.

replies.author: Brendan Phoebe
replies.text:
Lots of math needs to be taught like this. Even though there is a lot more in the topic of things like graphic functions than said in the video, everyone needs a basis to start on. You could teach a young child that 1+1=2, but if you were to try and teach them why 1+1=2 first, they would not have had the basis needed to understand what you're talking about first. 

Learning topics like graphic functions now allows us to progress further into math until we can tackle things like Calculus and truly understand what we had seen before.

@Pramudith Fernando you're probably right. We have 4+6+2 system instead of American 4+4+4.
In +2 you have to select between Arts, Commerce and Science.

I studied Physics Chemistry Biology Mathematics and German in +2.

The mathematics I learned in order to pass JEE adv was actually quite intense. You should look up JEE adv 2016 papers. Those maths questions seem difficult to me now even though I'm a physics post grad.

replies.author: Atlow
replies.text: College is just after 12th grade, so i don't know why you're so impressed by learning something 3 years earlier. Not to mention that there's no specific 'college math' in the United States, people take different classes based on their skill level. People can start with like a 980 class or a 1010 class if they aren't as accustomed to the subject, or they can start in a 1050 or 1080 class if they are more confident in their skills. In other words, yes, this is taught in college, but it's also taught in 10th or 11th grade if people take the higher math classes.

topLevelComment.author: Vedran Čačić
topLevelComment.text:
46:05 Over _real_ numbers, it _does_ factor. As (x-2sqrtx+2)(x+2sqrtx+2). But of course, over the rationals it doesn't. And even over the integers, there is no hard rule that "sum of squares doesn't factor". For example, (x^2)^2+2^2=(x^2-2x+2)(x^2+2x+2).

3:02:42 Common mistake. A cubic doesn't look remotely like that. It is tangent to abscissa at the origin, not passing at 45° angle like the y=x one. Same with sqrtx: it is tangent to the ordinate at zero. That mistake is particularly jarring since you draw it about 30 times later when explaining the coordinate transforms. :-(

3:14:30 People often say that, probably because they first see the y-transform and draw the wrong conclusion. It's the _coordinate system_ that's moving, not the graph, when we add to / subtract from the coordinates. x-2 instead of x moves the coordinate system 2 to the left, just as you would expect if you didn't see the y-transform first. Well, what about the y-transform, you say? Same thing, you just have to add to /subtract from the _y coordinate_, not the function value. So, it's y+2=sqrtx, and of course it moves the coordinate system 2 up.

3:36:29 Of course it's not a coincidence. :-)

3:50:06: By the same thinking, b shouldn't be 1 also, because it's also a constant function. :-P

3:51:00 Only for positive x. For negative x it's not even defined, so it makes even less sense.

5:12:37 No, these cannot happen in this context. Since exponential function (with base not 1) is injective, the transformed equation is exactly equivalent to the original one. In other words, those negative numbers will never appear under the log, since the value of exponential functions will always be positive. Of course, when you have more than one log, as in the next example, such thinking doesn't apply anymore, so maybe it's too complicated to know exactly when you should check the purported solutions---but I still think it's valuable to distinguish "checking to calm the nerves" (just to verify we didn't make a mistake) from "checking as an integral part of the solving" (when you submit your equation to the noninjective functions).

5:22:11 Ridiculous. If it's componded anually, then 3.54 years is in no way special. The answer is "4 years" if you interpret the question as "at least $2000", or "never" if you interpret it as "exactly $2000".

5:25:16 The overuse of ln is one of my pet peeves. Wouldn't it be easier to just take the log with the base 1.12, which is explicitly given in the equation? :-P

6:15:58 Well, it's obviously meant to be 1.75. Since h(x) is quadratic function with graph vertex at (1,2), and a=-1/4 (both of them, see 3:36:29;).

topLevelComment.author: Olivia12333
topLevelComment.text: I don’t think this is actually college material, I learned all of these topics in high school. The easiest math courses in college are usually calculus and linear algebra. Then again, it’s free, so I’m not complaining.

replies.author: Laura L
replies.text: @Olivia12333 Well, "College Algebra" is a commonly used course title across US community colleges serving people who need to consolidate their algebra~pre-calculus skills (hence the name "Algebra") before jumping into Calculus, so I don't think it's necessarily misleading to those who are familiar with the US college system at the very least.

replies.author: Olivia12333
replies.text: Renier C. Depone oh ok. That’s fair. But I think the title is a bit misleading because many people think this video covers all of college math—I keep seeing things like “why would I go to college when I could watch this”—but while the topics in this video may be offered in college they are not typically considered to be post secondary level math.

replies.author: Renier C. Depone
replies.text: If you go to freecodecamp's site it says that this is College Math prerequisites. Which in some college schools are taught to freshmen.

replies.author: Mahdi Dbouk
replies.text: @ClockFixer This is true for introductory level courses and usually such courses will suffice. However, if you're going into Data Science (The real thing). Memorizing a dozen of formulas without understanding the theory behind it will not be enough, and like in other mathematically based fields, you'll need to learn some proof based maths like Real Analysis and Advanced Algebra, which require university level education.

replies.author: ClockFixer
replies.text: @Mahdi Dbouk statistics, on the other hand, can be exhaustively learned with YouTube videos.

replies.author: Mahdi Dbouk
replies.text: @MATRIX EXPOSER You can learn on your own, nobody said you can't. However, how much could you learn about a subject by solely learning it on your own? It won't be 100%. Having someone with a Phd in the given subject to lead you through the material is not the same as having yourself, who knows nothing about the material. This is basic logic.
